messageBody:
On 2/19/07, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...> wrote:
> Perhaps I don't want separate tools, but a way to separate the tests
> into two categories: essential and coverage. The essential tests are the
> ones that drove my design decisions, while the coverage tests are the
> ones that I added to protect against future refactorings.

This is exactly the purpose of TestNG's groups. Over the years, I've
seen users define groups to indicate:

- The type of tests (unit, functional, integrations)
- What they test (database, front-end, security)
- Their execution speed (fast, slow)
- Platform-specific information (win32, linux, macos)
- Various other attributes (remote, multi-thread)

The category you mention (essential or coverage) seems like a valuable
addition to this categorization:

@Test(groups = { "fast", "database", "coverage" })
public void verifyIntegrity() { ... }
